> [{quoted}](name=Ralanr,realm=NA,application-id=Ir7ZrJjF,discussion-id=AQmM8w7I,comment-id=0003,timestamp=2016-04-21T15:22:44.563+0000)
>
> To be fair, sometimes the players know jack shit about balance.  A lot of the cries for nerfs are because people do not know how to fight a particular champion.

I'd agree IF the community hadn't reached a consensus. If there is a point for dispute, you'll always have bickering between those who know and those who don't have a clue about balance and Riot will always take it with a pinch of salt.

If there is a large consensus? Well. Who really knows the game better? The comparatively small team of developers? Or the millions of active players who play League of Legends without a monthly incentive?

>Well. Who really knows the game better? 

- The comparatively small team of developers with access to near limitless raw data about the game, and/or the ability to start gathering needed/wanted data on a whim.

VS

- The vocal minority that comes to the forums to comment on changes that normally affect them closely, but still out-numbers the Dev team notably.


You have to remember that the forums (and Reddit) are only a small % of the english community. There are also other countries with feedback that we almost never see.

1) I'm not sure data can say everything about how fun a game is
2) They don't seem to be paying much attention to data, at least they aren't paying attention to the same data we are

For example, a champion can have an exact 50% win rate, be fun to play but be really terrible to play against.  Data can't reveal that, only lots of playtesting will.  And sometimes it takes playing against that champs dozens of times, or certain weird playstyles arising from dirty nasty unintended builds to discover those weaknesses.  Even if the champ isn't 'broken', they can be unhealthy for the game.
Both sides have their pros and cons. But the question was "who knows the game better". I'm going to say the Dev team as the advantage over the forums.
